repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Using powershell as the default windows shell as using cmd alters $PATH
in a way that makes building neovim fail (powershell prioritizes visual
studio tools which is arguably more correct).

This was tested with gnu make for windows, which can be installed with
e.g. scoop. It does not work with nmake and it is extremely unlikely we
want to add nmake support as the makefile is merely supposed to be
syntactic sugar for the most common case. For similar reasons, the only
supported generator is ninja.

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
ifeq ($(OS),Windows_NT)
  SHELL := powershell.exe
  .SHELLFLAGS := -NoProfile -Command
  MKDIR := mkdir -force
  TOUCH := new-item -force
  CMAKE := cmake
  CMAKE_GENERATOR := Ninja
else
  MKDIR := mkdir -p
  TOUCH := touch
  CMAKE := $(shell (command -v cmake3 || echo cmake))
  CMAKE_GENERATOR ?= $(shell (command -v ninja > /dev/null 2>&1 && echo "Ninja") || echo "Unix Makefiles")
endif
```

Note: spaces (not tabs) are used here.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,3 +1,17 @@
+ifeq ($(OS),Windows_NT)
+SHELL := powershell.exe
+.SHELLFLAGS := -NoProfile -Command
+MKDIR := mkdir -force
+TOUCH := new-item -force
+CMAKE := cmake
+CMAKE_GENERATOR := Ninja
+else
+MKDIR := mkdir -p
+TOUCH := touch
+CMAKE := $(shell (command -v cmake3 || echo cmake))
+CMAKE_GENERATOR ?= $(shell (command -v ninja > /dev/null 2>&1 && echo "Ninja") || echo "Unix Makefiles")
+endif

comment_data.body: It doesn't seem to make any difference. The copyright text isn't shown anyway when using the makefile. Do you still want it? It doesn't harm of course, it just seems like it makes no difference but I don't mind adding it.
more of a "best practice" (avoiding unnecessary output could avoid accidental problems?)

comment_regular_data.body:
> Maybe fix performance? It's slow af for some reason. Low priority


Maybe try `-ExecutionPolicy Bypass` ?

> Maybe try -ExecutionPolicy Bypass ?

Benchmarking with hyperfine made no difference. I will experiment with cmd to see to see if that helps.
I give up on trying to improve performance for now. Powershell is just destined to be slow it seems. We can iterate on it in the future if we need to improve it.
Nice clean-up in any case, even for other platforms üëç

title: build: make makefile work on windows
